headline: Old-Fashioned Apple Dumplings
description: These apple dumplings are the ones my grandmother used to make: warm, flaky, apple-y, sweet, and drizzled with a sauce that's baked right with them.
name: Old-Fashioned Apple Dumplings
recipeIngredient: 6 large Granny Smith apples, peeled and cored

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Butter a 9x13-inch pan.

Roll pastry into a 24x16-inch rectangle on a lightly floured surface. Cut into six 8-inch squares. Place an apple on each pastry square with the cored opening facing upward. Cut butter into 8 pieces; place 1 piece in the opening of each apple; reserve the remaining butter for sauce.
Divide brown sugar between apples, poking some inside each cored opening and the rest around the base of each apple. Sprinkle cinnamon and nutmeg over apples.

Using slightly wet fingertips, bring one corner of the pastry square up to the top of the apple, then bring the opposite corner to the top and press together. Bring up the two remaining corners, and seal. Slightly pinch the dough at the sides to completely seal in the apple. Repeat with the remaining apples and place in the prepared baking dish.

Combine water, white sugar, vanilla extract, and reserved butter in a large saucepan. Place over medium heat, and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer until sugar is dissolved, about 5 minutes. Carefully pour the sauce over the dumplings.
Bake in the preheated oven for 50 to 60 minutes. Place each apple dumpling in a dessert bowl, and spoon some of the sauce over the top.

review.reviewBody: I followed the recipe exactly as posted except the sauce didn't thicken as expected, did I do something wrong.
I made it as exact as I could to recipe and it came out phenomenal. . I was trying to make these as close to my moms recipe and I might have come CLOSE. THANKS!

I made this for dessert on a beautiful Fall Sunday. They were so fun for my daughter and I to make together! After the first half hour I covered in foil. They came out beautifully! Just delicious as is or even better with some vanilla ice cream!

I read a few recipes and they are all pretty much similar to this olde fashioned one.. the only thing I altered is instead of water for the syrup I used apple cider.. they’re in the oven now and I can’t wait till they are done and cool a little bit before I can enjoy this first time I’ve made an apple dumpling ! Thanks to all who helped with this recipe!! -john G
Perfect recipe made twice. I added rum to the sauce! Wonderful served warm.

I liked the recipe. The only thing I did differently was I used crescent roll dough and I rolled it out. I cut up the apples and so I put everything on the dough, rolled it up, then sliced it into 10 pieces. when I was growing up, we called this "apple rings".

Iv made this recipe before but ig I read the ingredients wrong? I used Pillsbury biscuits and it was greats! Also I. Didnt like the idea of half an apple inside so I whent ahead and chopped them into small strips. Maybe go with cubed or thinly sliced. The strips where difficult to stuff the dough
Smells amazing!!
Used pre-made gf pie dough to make these and it was amazing!! Didn’t used much of the sauce before baking and I loved it! Def recommend and will make again!!!
Very good! Makes a lot of sauce so I only made half the amount the next time I made it and it was plenty.
As advertised! People cannot get enough…I’ve made 3 batches in 2 weeks. This time I added brandy and the aroma alone is divine!
Easy to follow. Definitely 5-star!
Fantastic recipe! Easy to make and delicious.
Easy to make and tastes great as well.
Delicious! Just like my mom and grandmother used to make. For the sauce I substituted the cinnamon for the vanilla. Will definitely make again.
Great recipe, but made more sauce than needed. Next time I will half that part.

I love the recipe but I had something gone wrong. I used granny Smith apples and it said to bake between 50-55 minutes . I took my out in 47 minutes I could see the tops getting a little to dark and the apples baked away and it was like applesauce inside the pastry. What do you think went wrong. There still taste great!
I loved how easy but amazing this recipe was! Please do an apple pie one!!!

This recipe is magnificent!
However, I tried this with Granny Smith (green) apples, and with honey crisp, and the honey crisp had by FAR the most flavor.
I also added 2 TBsp of cornstarch to the sauce because it was just too runny. Even so, the bottoms of the crusts were sopping wet. 
I suggest using honey crisp apples, adding 1/4 cup of cornstarch and 1/2 cup of water (for more sauce but keeping a tiny bit of thickness), and adding the sauce after the apples have been baking for 10 minutes so the bottoms have some kind of substance to them.
Happy baking!

FOLLOWED instructions for the sauce but all I got was hot liquid....I made my own sauce by melting butter then sugar then adding water as the sauce thickened to a more saucy consistency..


Otherwise great recipe!
This was so easy. Every one loved them and I will definitely be making them again and again I’m sure of it
Made as the recipe stated but used store bought refrigerated crust. Flavor was delicious. The bottom was a bit soggy from sitting in the sauce but didn’t seem to bother anyone.
ah.mazing! delicious! Smells like Autumn. Tastes like home
Used brown sugar instead of which and made them smaller. Excellent.

These are AMAZING! I made my own crust, did sucanat instead of brown sugar in the middle and used pink lady apples with the skin on. Every 10-15 minutes while baking I would spoon the sauce over the dumplings. Besides that I did what the recipe said. I’ve never made dumplings before but will definitely be making these again! Easy to make and delicious.
I had left over pie crust dough I wanted to use. This was delicious. I might try making the sauce with a different sweetener like honey.

I've been baking up a storm during this pandemic, and decided to add apple dumplings to the list. I used Crisco's classic pie crust recipe and made a few modifications. I halved the recipe, sliced the apples, and made 6 'mini' dumplings by using half an apple for each dumpling. The sauce is so delicious and could hardly wait for them to cool before gobbling them up! This will be a go-to...well worth the effort and time!
Great change from pie. The recipe was great.. Try to get best puff pastry available. And the best baking Apples.

I followed the instructions to a T and I used the ready made pie crusts. I made 6 apples and only 2 of the 6 didn't crumble all apart. Would anyone know why they would crumble? They tasted delicious but presentation didn't go over well. Thank you!
Delicious!! Will definitely make it again.
Delicious!!! A taste of old times and a family favorite!!!
Reminded me of the ones my mom used to make!
very good
OMG...it is incredible.

Wellllll, the apples were so large, that the pie crust was not reaching up around the tops, leaving a gaping apple. So I would not use ready made pie crusts again, like I had to today. I’m very new at things with CRUST but love to eat them! I love that there are very few ingredients, and they taste delicious together. No company coming, so I guess I’ll just try again,,,
Easy and turned out fabulous. Super for a rainy day dinner dessert.
Wonderful. Great taste. But instead of folding dough up over the apples from below. I cut a roll out pie crust in fourths and draped each over each apple (I just made 4 apples).
It turned out good. I thought it would be good to add Carmel on the top.

This is very similar to the recipe my Mom would make me for my birthday. Delicious, but we would slice the apples, like pie, and roll up in the dough. Here in Ohio, we liked to use the Jonathon apples--a sweet, tart apple that is great for baking. Granny Smiths aren't reliable.

Delicious. I used the Perfect Pie recipe from Simply as the pastry. I used Golden Delicious and Red Delicious. I goofed up the sauce, but it didn't need it. Cooked turkey at the same time and had the oven at 350 for 30 minutes then 15 minutes at 400. The sauce part was on top as a sorta sugar crust and it worked. Thank you for sharing this recipe. Probably going to be making it for family a lot more due to how scrumptious it is.
Added 2 more dumplings and used crescent roll pastry.

Yes, I made my crust using Alton Brown’s recipe—one on Food Network’s from 2004 approximately. Wow, yes it’s very time consuming but well worth the time/work. Firstly, I peeled & cored my apples (used Gala), then I sliced them & stacked. When I made the sauce, I added Caramel Extract—yummy! You’d think you’re eating a Carmel Apple! Overall this should be 5 stars!!!

I made the dumplings following the recipe exactly as written. I made the pie crust by hand and used Granny Smith apples. I boiled the sugar water for exactly 5 minutes then poured the mixture over the dumplings and placed the dish in a pre-heated oven. The outcome was the dumplings “boiled” in the syrupy liquid, the tops browning nicely and the bottoms having a texture of noodles. The syrupy fluid was still very deep in the dish after it was finished. After sitting for 30 minutes, the fluid thickened and reabsorbed into the dumplings. These were super sweet. I will not make these again- I disliked the texture and watery, overly sweet syrup.
My partner said it was better than apple pie because the crust stayed crisp and it was full of flavor.
I have made these 2 times adjusted by filling apple with nuts & raisins was so good & easy
I should have used a bigger baking dish as I had leftover sauce that didn't go in, but it is delicious.
I used Ree Drummonds Pie Crust ( i just love how it turns out for me with having an egg in it...- easy to manipulate) but used your sauce ... ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!
very good a little to much with glaze may be use brown sugar I will make again let you know in the mean time keep on baking
I agree with the negative reviews. Soooooo much water and sugar. I used to make apple dumplings years ago but couldn’t find my recipe.
Easy, delicious, and an instant favorite. I used Pillsbury Pie Crusts rather than homemade for less mess and less time.
My Dad says this is very similar to my grandmother’s recipe. He enjoyed them.
I liked it. But maybe family wasn't in the mood for this dessert. Husband did mention it was kinda sweet.
So yummy. I cheated and used frozen pie dough. Will definitely make it again.

Really good, but need to cut the sweetness. Maybe less inside the apples? Especially if you don't use GS apples (which I don't like) I like the idea of using brown sugar and cider for the sauce. I made a vanilla custard recipe from this site and put some of that on too, because that's how we served it at a restaurant I used to work at. (The 'n' Bull, Peddler's Village, Lahaska, PA)

I’m lactose intolerant and this is the first dessert I’ve made in six months that I’ve really LOVED!!!!! I just used 2 Great Value brand deep dish pie shells, thawed them, and used that dough. The rest of the recipe I followed exactly (vegan butter though), and everyone in my house loved it!
I really, really liked this pudding, I will definitely make these wonderful Apple dumplings again.
Delicious! Gained rave reviews from the family. I do think the next time I will decrease sugar in sauce or try honey in it. ... but it still gets 5 stars!
Reminded me of my childhood.... just like Grandma used to make
Absolutely loved it. Perfect, easy, and quick. Will definitely make again and again.
Simple and delicious.

AWSOME!!!! I have been looking for a recipe with a good topping and I found it. I did make my crust that I use for pies and it was perfect. I used Jonathan apples instead of granny’s and the taste was super good. This will be the only recipe I will ever make and I will be making it again and again.
They were wonderful and smelled so good while they were baking--- it made everyone want them before supper. I made they wait. Thanks P.G.

Its too sweet, use less white sugar and a cup less water. Dont have any open areas of pie crust dough! I think it would be better with half the butter in the apple, only 1 tbls of brown sugar and sprinkle some cinnamon over the peeled apple before closing. Next time I will make pie crust out of 1.5 cups cold flour, salt and 1/2 cup of lard 2 times to make sure I have enough dough.

DON’T DO THE SAUCE!!! Even after cutting the “sauce” (simple sugar) recipe in half (no way it would all fit in the pan), these are just mush. I useful my favorite tried and true crust recipe and the dumplings are delicious on top, where the crust is flaky and amazing and the apples are tender, but everything below the “sauce line” is just an unbaked sugar and crust goo. I’ve put them back in the oven after removing one dumpling and trying to scoop out some of the sickly sweet sauce, and I hope they’ll crisp enough to be edible.
No changes. It was delicious, my husband loved it. I will make it again.
OUTSTANDING! None compares! Perfect every time!
I used pilsbury pie crust and it came out amazing!!!

I was hoping for something close to what my mother always made, but (forgive me) this recipe blows anything she ever made out of the water! I ran short on butter and it was still perfect. One of those apple peeler/corer gizmos is key.

Extremely tasty! I will be using this recipe again.
 Repeating! Super easy and still very tasty!
Whole family lived them! My husband told me to please keep this recipe.

I tried this for the first time they came out great and everybody loved them.
Don't think I did too bad for my first time..Thank you for this..!
Very, very yummy! I won the approval of my mother and my great aunt. The only thing I would suggest is making about 1/6 of the liquid drizzle…this recipe calls for wayyyyy too much.

I used this recipe simply for the “sauce”. I used canned crescent rolls and canned apple pie filling. This was a super quick and easy desert. I baked mine for 40 min on 400 degrees, and they’re now a staple desert at my house!! Oh and they’re great if you have to stick them in the fridge and reheat in the oven.

THis did not work at all. There was no way a double pastry recipe could fit around 4 apples without tearing to bits, much less 6 like in the recipe. I ended up baking the apples with cinnamon, brown sugar, and raisins in a pan without the pastry.

Amazing recipe! I used the buttery flaky crust recipe. I sprinkled brown sugar in the outer crust before baking. Then basted with the sauce at 30 and 50 minutes. The last 5 minutes I turned on low broil and basted with the sauce to brown a bit. My kids did a magic trick of making them disappear lol. I did also boil the sauce in the microwave as another reviewer mentioned.
Mixed up some vanilla pudding and, while still warm, drizzled over the dumplings! Like angels dancing on your tongue!
A new family favorite!
Heaven in a bowl!
I will make this again. It really was easy and sooo delicious. My idea of comfort food.
Wow! So delicious.

Excellent! This is my go-to desert for Holidays, special occasions,etc. I follow the directions as they are listed and it turns out superb every time! You cannot go wrong with this apple dumpling recipe!

If I could give this 0 stars I would. This recipe was great up until the sauce. 3 cups of water is a rediculous amount of water and I knew better. I thought to myself just to do what the recipe says, with this being my first time making them. I followed everything exactly and when I pulled them out of the oven, the sauce was boiling over and my dumplings were nothing but mushy pie crust and sauce. Absolutely awful, everything went into the trash.
These Old Fashioned Apple Dumplings were delicious!! I have a peeler/corer/slicer in one, so my dumplings broke open & slid everywhere, but that didn't make them any less delicious!!
Easy enough recipe. I made the crust from scratch. I would change one thing that would make it a lot better--use less sugar. It was way too sweet.

I had huge Granny Smith apples, so I used my apple slicer and put about 3/4 apple on each pie crust. Otherwise followed recipe as written. Was delicious but I thought the pie crust was a little gummy on the bottom and a little overcooked on the top. An idea: use some of the apple slices on the bottom to elevate the crust-covered apples. Foil sheet just laid over tops for 7-10 minutes may prevent dryness. Will also back off on sugar; was very sweet. Will try again.
Next time I'll try the caramel sauce another reviewer suggested. Cut the recipe down drastically to 3 apples. But this recipe is a keeper!

This was a very delicious dish but a bit finicky to prepare. I used big apples and some small ones. Think I would go with small-medium sized apples as you can eat a lot less pastry. I added pecans to the recipe but didn't make the sauce. It just sounded like too much sugar to me. I guess the dumplings leaked a bit while baking so that made some sauce with not as much sugar content. They were very tasty though and would make them again.
We loved them! I wouldn't change a thing. I made these Christmas Eve, we actually had them with vanilla ice cream for dinner. I think I started a new, delicious tradition!

I do not cook but was able to make this, and if I do say so myself (which I do), it was phenomenal! I followed comments on crust recipe that said use very cold water and add slowly and crust turned out great. I followed other parts of recipe pretty much exactly and, wow, it was good. The only thing I might change is to add less sugar to the sauce; it is definitely on the sweet side. That said - I will absolutely cook these again!

I was curious about some of the reviews stating this was "too sweet" but I took a chance because most old fashioned desserts were sweeter than those of today. Yes, they're sweet - yes, they're old fashioned -- yes, they are awesome! I rolled out only part of the dough at a time to make it easier to work with. I also used Granny Smith apples, as they are nice and tart, and worked to balance the sweetness. These are very reminiscent of heirloom apple dumplings.

I used store bought pie dough, and stuffed pinches of allspice, nutmeg, and clove into the apple cavities along with the butter and brown sugar. The sauce is very sweet: I think next time I make it I will use 1/3 cup less sugar. Overall, a tasty dumpling, perfect á la mode.
This was good, but I ended up substituting my Mother's sauce because it only had a Tbsp butter and less sugar. Thank you for sharing this recipe.

OMG! Easy and delicious. 
The sauce was sweet and thick and complimented the "dumplings" A huge hit!! 
Will make again and again!
No changes

These have been made for generations in my family. I do have these suggestions based on person preference..
(1) I slice the apples and put them in a plastic bag with the spices (and I add some apple pie spice) and shake, thus coating each apple piece. 
(2) I then place several slices onto each pastry square rather than an entire apple.
(3) I put the seamed side down in the pan and pour the sugar water over.
(4) About midway during baking I also spoon the sauce over the tops. 
The first time I made these for my grandmother she stopped and looked at me and said appreciatively "these taste just like mama's!"
The best apple dumpling i've ever had. It was a hit with the family.

This is my all time favorite recipe! Simply delicious. I used premade pie crusts and an apple peeler-corer-slicer machine. Makes it super fast! I also like to put mine in individual ramekins. Great with a scoop of vanilla ice cream!
I have made this recipe totally from scratch & have now made it 3X total in the past 2 weeks. It is easy, just stick to recipe. Love love love them!

I'm surrounded by apple orchards, so when Honey Crisps come in, I do fried apples, then apples for lunch, then this. So far I see no point in making dumplings any other way, and the only change I make to the recipe is bumping up the spices a bit. (I do use premade pie crusts.)
